description: Pipes, redirects, environment variables, process management, and terminal productivity

cards.front: What does the pipe operator | do in the terminal?
cards.back:
Sends the output of one command as input to another.

ls *.py | wc -l            # count Python files
cat app.log | grep "error"  # find error lines
du -sh * | sort -rh | head -5  # 5 largest files

Chain commands together to build powerful one-liners.

cards.front: What do > and >> do in the terminal?
cards.back:
>  writes output to a file (overwrites)
>> appends to a file

python script.py > output.txt     # overwrite
echo "new line" >> output.txt      # append
python script.py 2> errors.txt    # redirect errors
python script.py &> all.txt       # redirect both

cards.front: What are environment variables and how do you use them?
cards.back:
Key-value pairs available to all processes. Used for configuration.

# Set (bash/zsh):
export API_KEY="abc123"

# Read in Python:
import os
os.environ["API_KEY"]  # "abc123"
os.environ.get("API_KEY", "default")

# View all:
env  # or printenv

cards.front: What does Ctrl+C do in the terminal?
cards.back:
Sends SIGINT — interrupts (stops) the running program.

Use when:
- A program is stuck in an infinite loop
- A server is running and you want to stop it
- A command is taking too long

Ctrl+Z suspends (pauses) instead of stopping.
Ctrl+D sends EOF (end of file) — exits the Python REPL.

cards.front: What is the difference between $PATH and other environment variables?
cards.back:
$PATH tells the shell where to find executable programs.

echo $PATH
# /usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin

When you type python, the shell searches each directory in PATH.
If python is not in PATH, you get "command not found."

Other env vars (like API_KEY) are application-specific configuration.

cards.front: How do you run a command in the background?
cards.back:
Add & at the end:
python server.py &

The terminal is free for other commands.

jobs        # list background jobs
fg          # bring last job to foreground
fg %1       # bring job 1 to foreground
kill %1     # stop job 1

cards.front: What are useful terminal shortcuts for productivity?
cards.back:
Tab — autocomplete file/command names
Up arrow — previous command
Ctrl+R — search command history
Ctrl+A — move to start of line
Ctrl+E — move to end of line
Ctrl+L — clear screen
!! — repeat last command

These work in bash, zsh, and most shells.

cards.front: How do you chain commands with && and ;?
cards.back:
&& — run next command only if previous SUCCEEDED
;  — run next command regardless

mkdir build && cd build  # cd only if mkdir works
python test.py && echo "PASS"  # echo only if tests pass
python test.py; echo "Done"    # echo always runs

Use && for dependent commands, ; for independent ones.
